creator: svanderger@rambler.ru
summary: Thread locking in main process after opening many (~40) pinned tabs and closing all unpined

comments.text:
User Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; Win64; x64; rv:52.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/52.0
Build ID: 20100101

Steps to reproduce:

1. Create new profile (windows 8.1 x64)
2. Install Tab Center Redux (or Tree Style Tab - webext from git, don't matter)
3. Open many tabs (~40) and pin them all exclude one (by using extension from step 2)
4. Close tab which not pinned
See what in main process thread locked (or cycle stucked, using one logical core).
Mozregression pointed on this:
Last good

comments.text: Andy, this seems specific to webextensions. Not sure what's causing this, the profiler doesn't seem to be catching the relevant thread that's using up CPU, nor does debugging the add-on in question.
comments.author: gijskruitbosch+bugs@gmail.com

comments.text: Can reproduce, we'll investigate.
comments.author: andy+bugzilla@mckay.pub

comments.text:
https://perfht.ml/2yjbasw
﻿https://www.dropbox.com/s/829zs3nrgbt9xij/cpu.mov?dl=0
comments.author: andy+bugzilla@mckay.pub

comments.text: Is this really a P1, and for 57? Please either assign an owner or reset flags as appropriate.
comments.author: dolske@mozilla.com

comments.text:
It was a P1 for us to investigate. By looking at the perf data, Kris found that the issue wasn't the extensions themselves, but in the tab strip implementation. When there are so many pinned tabs in the tab strip, closing a tab causes lots of repaints in the tab strip and that sends CPU usage really high.

It's extremely rare for a large number of pinned tabs, so probably should not be a P1, so I've dropped it to a P2. But based upon the above information, Dao might want to re-prioritize.
comments.author: andy+bugzilla@mckay.pub

comments.text:
I can reproduce the CPU crazy consumption without ant extensions

Reproducible: always

Steps To Reproduce:
1. Open 5-6 pinned tab and no normal tab
2. Reduce browser window width so that New Tab Button[+] will overlap with window controls button

OR
1. Open 7-8 pinned tab and no normal tab
2. Enable menubar and/or titlebar
3. Reduce browser window width so that New Tab Button[+] will overlap with right side window border

Actual Results:
[+] button blinks(repaints) forever. And CPU usage increases.
comments.author: alice0775@yahoo.co.jp

comments.text: Alice, any chance you can take a performance profile with https://perf-html.io/ and share it here?
comments.author: gijskruitbosch+bugs@gmail.com

comments.text:
https://perfht.ml/2ACgtlT
(8 pinned tabs of about:blank, latter str of comment#6)
comments.author: alice0775@yahoo.co.jp

comments.text: :kats, looking at https://perfht.ml/2AFLG7N - it seems that we spend a *lot* of time in "AsyncScrollPortEvent" and in restyles coming from there as well as more generally. I don't know enough about APZ and layout to know exactly where the issue is myself, but I'm hoping the profile has enough information for someone like you - see also comment 6 for some STR which may help. Is there any chance you can take a look and figure out where in Core we could improve some of this (or if there's something exceptionally dumb we're doing on the frontend side of things that we could change to improve performance here) ? Thank you!
comments.author: gijskruitbosch+bugs@gmail.com

comments.text: The AsyncScrollPortEvent doesn't appear to be APZ-specific; the "Async" seems to just refer to the fact that it's run in another spin of the event loop. This stuff predates APZ and I'm not familiar with it, maybe Timothy or Mats will have a better idea of what's going on.
comments.author: bugmail@mozilla.staktrace.com

comments.text:
This has nothing to do with APZ. The code that tries to resize overflowed tabs to fit in the available space just doesn't handle the case where all tabs are pinned properly. It triggers an infinite reflow loop by triggering a new reflow from events triggered by the last reflow.

See the regression range for the responsible patch.
comments.author: kmaglione+bmo@mozilla.com

comments.text:
Created attachment 8951555
Bug 1404469 - Don't take pinned tabs outside of the scrollbox when there are no unpinned tabs.

Review commit: https://reviewboard.mozilla.org/r/220874/diff/#index_header
See other reviews: https://reviewboard.mozilla.org/r/220874/
comments.author: dao+bmo@mozilla.com

comments.text:
The attached patch fixes the bug as far as I can reproduce it. However, this weird-looking state can still be reached if there's an unpinned tab:

(In reply to Alice0775 White from comment #6)
> 2. Reduce browser window width so that New Tab Button[+] will overlap with
> window controls button

Ideally we would prevent this when we know that the pinned tabs are too wide / won't leave enough room for the scrollbox, but I'm not sure how we can reliably do that without flushing layout (and calling _positionPinnedTabs in a resize event listener, which I think we currently don't).
comments.author: dao+bmo@mozilla.com

comments.text:
What's the expected behaviour with this patch if I have only pinned tabs and then open a new tab? What I'm seeing is that the new tab goes into the scrollbox with the pinned tabs. If I then resize the window to make it "big enough" and then make it smaller again, this stops being the case.

It's not clear to me if this is expected. Perhaps we just don't care because it's only meant to fix the CPU usage / weird layout stuff, not actually make this all that workable a state to be in as a user (because, frankly, that's not really possible)?
comments.author: gijskruitbosch+bugs@gmail.com

comments.text:
Comment on attachment 8951555
Bug 1404469 - Don't take pinned tabs outside of the scrollbox when there are no unpinned tabs.

(In reply to :Gijs from comment #18)
> What's the expected behaviour with this patch if I have only pinned tabs and
> then open a new tab? What I'm seeing is that the new tab goes into the
> scrollbox with the pinned tabs. If I then resize the window to make it "big
> enough" and then make it smaller again, this stops being the case.

Yeah, when you make it smaller again that's the situation I described in comment 17.

> It's not clear to me if this is expected. Perhaps we just don't care because
> it's only meant to fix the CPU usage / weird layout stuff, not actually make
> this all that workable a state to be in as a user (because, frankly, that's
> not really possible)?

It's possible (basically let pinned tabs scroll when they consume too much space), but I still don't see a cheap enough fix and I don't think we care enough to accept a performance hit.
